TONIGHT ON THE CBS EVENING 
      NEWSHere is an early preview of what Awe 
      are planning for tonight’s CBS EVENING NEWS from Anchor and Managing 
      Editor, Katie Couric… Hi everyone, Tonight we’ll 
      continue our coverage of the tragedy at Virginia Tech. Bob Orr will 
      report new details on the investigation into the life of the gunman, Cho 
      Seung-Hui. In college, Cho was so introverted that his own roommates 
      barely knew him. Sharyn Alfonsi will share her interview with one 
      of the students who lived closest to Cho. Meanwhile, Attorney 
      General Alberto Gonzales was on the hot seat in a Senate hearing on the 
      firing of eight federal prosecutors who some Democrats say were improperly 
      dismissed. Jim Axelrod will have the story. And we’ll have a new 
      CBS News poll on the subject. And Dr. Jon LaPook will share 
      the results of research that offers the strongest evidence yet that 
      menopause hormones could raise the risk of breast cancer. Rates of the 
      cancer plunged in 2003 after millions of women stopped taking hormones and 
      breast cancer rates stayed at the lame level in 2004, adding to the 
      evidence against use of menopause hormones. And one day after the 
      Supreme Court affirmed the legality of the Partial Birth Abortion Ban Act, 
      our correspondent Wyatt Andrews will take a look at the impact of 
      the ruling. It's the start of what is going to be a long, intense debate. 
      Finally, Jerry Bowen will have the story of an 
      extraordinary man battling a crippling disease. So far, he’s winning: Last 
      week he crossed the finish line of the Boston Marathon. Thanks, 
      and I hope you’ll join us tonight. Katie
For more information on these stories, please click on the 
      following links: Va. Tech Killer Picked On, Classmates

TONIGHT ON DAVID 
      LETTERMANJoin Dave tonight on The Late 
      Show with actor/comedian Gary Shandling AND American 
      Chopper stars Paul Teutul Sr. and Jr... Plus, musical guests Tokyo 
      Police Club! 



FRIDAY MORNING ON THE EARLY SHOWHarry Smith, 
      Russ Mitchell and Tracy Smith anchor THE EARLY 
      SHOW from New York. Julie Chen anchors from Los Angeles. 
      Dave Price will bring us the weather. Hannah Storm is off. 
      Along with the top news of the day, we will also have the 
      following stories: STUDY HALL - STUDENT ENTREPRENEURS: 
      For a teenager, what's cooler than being captain of the football team? 
      Well, how about owning a million dollar company? There was a time when if 
      you wanted to be popular in high school you tried out for football or the 
      cheerleading squad. But now, there is a new way for kids to really shine. 
      All you have to do start your own company. Friday morning, we'll meet two 
      high schoolers who did just that. DEAN CAIN IN CROSSROADS - A 
      STORY OF FORGIVENESS: In a movie inspired by real events, 
      Crossroads: A Story of Forgiveness, paints the difficult portrait 
      of the tragic consequences of reckless driving. A remorseful student 
      speaks out about the dangers of careless driving and how one mistake 
      behind the wheel can change things for good. As Dean Cain, who we all 
      remember from The Adventures of Lois & Clark, portrays Bruce 
      Murakami, a man whose wife and daughter are killed in a terrible car 
      accident. Cain brings a vulnerability to the role and it is a pleasant 
      departure for the actor, from portraying the Man of Steel on the small 
      screen. Friday morning, we will speak with Dean Cain about the importance 
      of this film and the message it conveys. HIDDEN TREASURE: 
      If you have ever dreamed about finding hidden treasure in your home, then 
      this story just might give you hope. Two Renaissance paintings bought 
      forty years ago for two hundred dollars, have sold for 3.4 million dollars 
      in an auction in England. And for years, they hung behind the spare room 
      door in an elderly woman's home. CBS News Correspondent Sheila 
      MacVicar will take a look at these valuable paintings. If you 
      would like more information on any of these stories or the broadcast, 
      please click on the following address and e-mail us: earlyshow@cbs.com 




 
SATURDAY 
      ON 48 HOURS
Here's a note from Bill Lagattuta on Saturday's 
      48 Hours Mystery, NIGHTMARE IN NAPA: 
      "Our story this week sounds a lot like the plot of one of those 
      Hollywood slasher flicks. But this story really happened. Two young women 
      viciously murdered in their home by an unknown attacker with a knife who 
      disappeared into the night. And it happened on Halloween. The scene of the 
      crime was the beautiful Napa Valley, America's premiere wine country in 
      California. That made the crime seem even more brutal because killings 
      like that are unheard of in Napa. As we covered the story of the crime 
      three years ago, the killer was still at large and the chance of finding 
      him began to dwindle with each passing month. The families grew frustrated 
      as police seemed unable to turn up new evidence or find suspects. And then 
      it happened... an ending to this story almost a year to the month of the 
      murders. I won't spoil it... the accused killer is someone no one 
      suspected. I hope you'll join us on Saturday night." - Bill 
      Lagattuta 48 Hours Mystery airs Saturdays at 
      10pmET/PT FOR MORE ON THIS STORY, WHY NOT READ THE 
      BOOK? 48 Hours Mystery, Nightmare in 
      Napa is now available in bookstores and online at 
      Amazon.com Click Here. This is the first in a brand 
      new series of true crime books published by Simon and Schuster, Pocket 
      Books. Here's more from 48 Hours 
      producer and author Paul LaRosa. "Nightmare in Napa 
      is the first in a series of true crime books based on the broadcasts of 
      CBS News' 48 Hours Mystery. It is the 
      chilling story of what happened to two women in a house in Napa, 
      California on Halloween night, 2004. 48 Hours 
      Mystery already had produced an hour on the story when Executive 
      Producer Susan Zirinsky and Executive Editor Al Briganti 
      hatched the idea to do a series of true crime books. They asked me to get 
      involved and write the first book because I had then recently published a 
      true crime book of my own called Tacoma Confidential. I 
      began reviewing all the tapes from the Napa broadcast and, as always, 
      there were a lot. That's something most viewers do not realize. In 
      producing any hour for 48 Hours Mystery, producers typically 
      will supervise the videotaping of more than one hundred hours of 
      interviews and other material. All of those hours are edited down to make 
      a compelling, fast-moving, one-hour broadcast for prime-time television. 
      This should give you an idea of the wealth and breadth of material we 
      compile for each broadcast. Because of time restrictions, a lot of 
      material never makes it onto the air. So much is left out that, well, you 
      could write a book, and that's just what we're going to do in this series. 
      Just under three-hundred, thirty-minute tapes existed for the 
      first hour. I went through a good portion of them but decided I had to go 
      to Napa and meet the principals and get a feel for the town and the Napa 
      Valley. So that's what I did. I got to meet, have lunch with or email many 
      of those involved with the story. In some cases, I did original reporting. 
      The original hour ended with the arrest of the murderer but now the case 
      had to wind its way through the courts. I followed it every step of the 
      way, culminating with the dramatic sentencing of the defendant in January, 
      2007. Along the way, I got a real sense for the lives of the two 
      murder victims: Adriane Insogna and Leslie Mazzara, and I hope that I've 
      been true to their memories in the book. They were both special young 
      women whose families are heartbroken by their loss. In many ways, the most 
      surprising aspect of the story is not the murder itself but the identity 
      of the murderer and his reasons for doing what he did. To buy the 
      book: Click Here I can't wait until you 
      read it and please send along your comments. My email is PLR@CBSNEWS.COM or look at my website: PaulLaRosa.com Click Here." Thanks, Paul 
      LaRosa If you would like more information on any of these stories 
      or the broadcast, please click on the following address and e-mail us at: 
      48hours@cbsnews.com 


SUNDAY 
      ON 60 MINUTES
 
MIND OF AN ASSASSIN: Few people know 
      more about the minds of assassins than those protecting the president of 
      the U.S. Secret Service intelligence officers compare their research to 
      the characteristics of the Virginia Tech shooter. Scott Pelley 
      reports. LIFE IN BAGHDAD: Bombs, shootings and long gas 
      lines are some of the obstacles that residents of Iraq's capital city must 
      deal with daily to survive. Lara Logan reports. STOP 
      SNITCHIN': Anderson Cooper reports on how the hip-hop culture's 
      message not to cooperate with the police in any way has undermined efforts 
      to solve murders across the country.
